description: The National Sleep Research Resource (NSRR) subject identifier links the subject's data and files.

CMT consisted of education on sleep hygiene, healthy lifestyle, and nasal dilator strips for use during sleep. ME consisted of a behavioral intervention to improve CPAP adherence, as described in [Bakker et al.2017 (PMCID: PMC4980541)](https://www.ncbi.nlm.nih.gov/pmc/articles/PMC4980541/).
Randomized participants were stratified by site. The site location has been recoded because it is an identifier.

units: milliliters per minute per 1.73 meters squared (mL/min per 1.73 m2)

display_name: PROMIS Sleep Disturbance: Satisdied with my sleep (past 7 days)
description:
Item from the PROMIS Sleep Disturbance instrument. [Yu L et al, 2012 (PMID: 22250775)](https://www.ncbi.nlm.nih.gov/pmc/articles/PMC3261577/)

[Search for all PROMIS SRI variables within this dataset](https://sleepdata.org/datasets/bestair/variables?search=promissd)

Calculated - Summary score for the PROMIS Sleep Disturbance instrument. Each item ranges from 1 to 5. The raw score is the sum of 8 items, and the T-score is identified by looking up total raw score in a T-score table. The T-score is categorized as: <55 (none to slight), 55.0 to 59.9 (mild), 60.0 to 69.9 (moderate), and >=70 (severe). [Yu L et al, 2012 (PMID: 22250775)](https://www.ncbi.nlm.nih.gov/pmc/articles/PMC3261577/)

[Search for all PROMIS SRI variables within this dataset](https://sleepdata.org/datasets/bestair/variables?search=promissd)

folder: Sleep Questionnaires/Sleep Disturbance/PROMIS Sleep Related Impairment
description:
Summary score for the PROMIS Sleep-Related Impairment instrument. Each item ranges from 1 to 5. The total score is derived by summing all 8 items and divided by the number of answered items. Higher score indicates more severe sleep related impairment.[Yu L et al, 2012 (PMID: 22250775)](https://www.ncbi.nlm.nih.gov/pmc/articles/PMC3261577/)

[Search for all PROMIS SRI variables within this dataset](https://sleepdata.org/datasets/bestair/variables?search=promissri)

folder: Sleep Questionnaires/Sleep Disturbance/Women's Health Initiative Insomnia Rating Scale (WHIIRS)
display_name: Total score of the Women's Health Initiative Insomnia Rating Scale (WHIIRS)
description:
Calculated - The Women’s Health Initiative Insomnia Rating Scale (WHIIRS) has 5 items. Each item is scored on a 5 point scale (from 0-4). The total score is the sum of all five items ranging from 0 to 20. Higher score indicates more severe insomnia. A score of 9 or higher is considered clinically significant insomnia.

Reference: [Levine, D. W., Kaplan, R. M., Kripke, D. F., Bowen, D. J., Naughton, M. J., & Shumaker, S. A. (2003). Factor structure and measurement invariance of the Women's Health Initiative Insomnia Rating Scale. Psychological Assessment, 15, 123-136.](https://www.ncbi.nlm.nih.gov/pubmed/12847773) [Levine et al.(2003)](https://psycnet.apa.org/record/2003-06188-004)

[Search for all WHIIRS variables within this dataset](https://sleepdata.org/datasets/bestair/variables?search=whiirs)

folder: Sleep Questionnaires/Sleep Disturbance/Women's Health Initiative Insomnia Rating Scale (WHIIRS)
description: Pick the answer that best describes how often you experienced the situation in the LAST 4 WEEKS. 7E. Did you take sleeping pills to help you sleep?

display_name: Apnea-Hypopnea Index: (All apneas with no oxygen desaturation threshold used + hypopneas with > 30% flow reduction and with >= 4% oxygen desaturation) / hour of sleep from type III home sleep apnea test
description: Calculated - Summary metric of sleep disordered breathing events. The definition of hypopnea events is consistent with the following clinical guidelines: (1) AASM 2012 update (recommended) [Berry RB et al. 2012 (PubMed ID:23066376)] (https://www.ncbi.nlm.nih.gov/pubmed/23066376), and (2) AASM 2015 (acceptable) [Berry RB et al. The AASM Manual for the Scoring of Sleep and Associated Events: Rules, Terminology and Technical Specifications, Version 2.2. American Academy of Sleep Medicine, Darien, IL, 2015.].

display_name: Cannula flow/pressure hours of useable signal
Sleep Efficiency: the proportion of sleep duration in in-bed period from type III polysomnography
description: Calculated. Sleep duration is the interval between sleep onset time and lights on/out-bed time while asleep, while in-bed period is the interval between lights off/in-bed time and lights on/out-bed time. Conventionally, this variable could be described as the ratio between total sleep time (TST) and time in bed (TIB).

display_name: Wake After Sleep Onset: the total duration between sleep onset and lights-on/out-bed time while being awake from type III polysomnography
Apnea-Hypopnea Index : (All apneas + hypopneas with >=30% nasal cannula [or alternative sensor] reduction with >= 4% oxygen desaturation) / hour of sleep
description:
Harmonized by the NSRR team.

The definition of hypopnea events is consistent with the following clinical guidelines: (1) AASM 2012 update (alternative) [Berry RB et al. 2012 (PubMed ID:23066376)](https://www.ncbi.nlm.nih.gov/pubmed/23066376), and (2) AASM 2015 (acceptable) [Berry RB et al. The AASM Manual for the Scoring of Sleep and Associated Events: Rules, Terminology and Technical Specifications, Version 2.2. American Academy of Sleep Medicine, Darien, IL, 2015.].

Data collected with no EEGs. Refer to the source for detailed definition for respiratory events: :ahi_primary:
